result.title: Objective
result.description: A financially sustainable new National Protected Area System is designed and under initial implementation in Chile

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Increase in financial capacity of protected areas system in Chile as measured through improvement in the Total Average Score for all PA sub-systems in the UNDP Financial Scorecard (Annex 7) that includes 3 components as follows:

baseline.comment: Total score 28.29 (or 14.5%)

actual.comment:
The results of application of the UNDP Financial Scorecard (FS) for 2015 will be available in September 2015.
Note: So far, an analysis of the results reported for the baseline year and for 2011, 2013 and 2014 has been carried out, and in particular, of the qualitative data (Part II of the FS), in order to determine the assumptions and biases each time the scorecard was completed, since this provides necessary context for application of the 2015 version, planned for August 2015.
Generally speaking, the average results reported by all respondents in 2013 and 2014 represent a slight improvement in comparison with the baseline, while the results reported in 2011 are well above the trends observed and account for almost 40% of the target set for the end of the project. Meanwhile, the quantitative data (Part I of the FS) show steady growth over time before exceeding the target set for the end of the project (for the National System of State-Protected Wildlife Areas (SNASPE): direct fiscal contribution increased from USD 6.75 million in 2009 to USD 12.9 million in 2014; own revenue increased from USD 6.15 million in 2009 to USD 10.8 million in 2014).
The differences between the quantitative results and the perceptions of the respondents may be linked with the following factors: i) they have a different understanding of the same questions at different times (for example, the existence of "funds" or "methods for allocating funds across sites"); ii) the number and profile of the respondents and institutions represented are different each year; iii) uncertainties and expectations regarding legal and institutional initiatives or specific project activities for funding for the protected area that could improve the perception in certain contexts (for example, "Payment for Environmental Services (PES) schemes"); and iv) different government administrations and their respective priorities (the project has been implemented in 3 different governments).
And, as part of an assessment on strategic management for the financial sustainability of the National System of Protected Areas (SNAP), the project is carrying out a critical analysis of the Financial Scorecard and how it applies to budget allocation in Chile (Saieh, 2015, in progress).

indicator.description: 2. Strengthened capacity for PA management, as measured by an increase in the Total Capacity Development Score for all PA Institutions Combined in the UNDP-GEF Capacity Scorecard (Annex 6)

baseline.comment:
Total score 42 (44%)
(averages for three levels in the cells below)

target.comment:
Total score of 70 (73%)
(averages for three levels in the cells below)

actual.comment:
The results of application of the UNDP-GEF Capacity Development Scorecard (CDS) for 2015 will be available in September 2015.
Note: Application of the 2015 CDS will be in August 2015. An analysis of the results reported in previous years (2011 and 2013) shows moderate improvements at the institutional level and relatively stable trends at the systemic and individual levels. It is important to note that over the last two years, the project has executed a number of important capacity building initiatives (for example, the creation of the National Protected Areas Committee, training courses for park rangers, the launch of the National Registry of Protected Areas and the strengthening of standards for management planning) and has provided technical support for preparing and discussing legal initiatives for creating SNAP, which could have a positive impact on results for 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description: 4. Reduction in gap between available funding and levels needed for management to meet established standards for SNAP and its PAs

baseline.comment: 66% (to be reconfirmed and adjusted by year 2)

target.comment: 30%, and agreed upon financing strategy to close gap within 5 years of project end

actual.comment:
The results of application of the UNDP Financial Scorecard (FS) for 2015 (Part I) will be available in September 2015.
Note: Considering the SNASPE budget section only (direct fiscal contribution and operating revenue), the executed budget in 2014 amounted to approximately USD 24 million (which represents a gap of 34% for the basic scenario and 53% for the optimal scenario, according to the scenarios described in the 2015-2030 financial strategy).

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The legal, strategic and operational framework is functioning for the sustainable financing of a new integrated National System of Protected Areas (SNAP)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Strengthened Governance frameworks for sustainable PA financing, as measured by increased scores in following 9 elements of Component 1 of UNDP Financial scorecard:
1.1 Legal, policy and regulatory support for revenue generation by PAs
1.2 Legal, policy and regulatory support for revenue sharing within the PA system
1.3 Legal and regulatory conditions for establishing endowment or trust funds
1.4 Legal, policy and regulatory support for alternative institutional arrangements for PA management
1.5 National PA financing strategies
1.6 Economic valuation of PA systems
1.7 Improved government budgeting for PA systems
1.8 Clearly defined institutional responsibilities for PA management and financing
1.9 Well-defined staffing requirements, profiles and incentives at site and system level

actual.comment: The results of application of the UNDP Financial Scorecard (FS) for 2015 will be available in September 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. General Law of SNAP and supporting regulations (including strategies and regulations for system wide and private protected areas)

baseline.comment: National PA Policy is not supported by a General Law for SNAP

target.comment: General Law of SNAP presented for approval to the National Congress by end of 2009; and approved and operational by end of project

actual.comment: The draft bill creating the Biodiversity and Protected Areas Service (SBAP) and the National Protected Areas System (SNAP) was largely approved by the Chilean Senate's Environment Committee in December 2014 and by the full Senate on March 4, 2015 (with 29 votes in favor and 2 abstentions). The President and Senators are currently making observations on the draft bill. In this context, the project is providing technical assistance to help with the analysis and organization of these observations, and the preparation of institutional development proposals for SNAP and SBAP. The focus of these efforts is improving the key aspects associated with defining SNAP, the categories of protected areas, support areas (conservation landscapes, buffer areas and biological corridors) and economic instruments (the biodiversity fund, compensation schemes, concession schemes and certifications), and developing technical arguments for staffing requirements (at the central, regional and protected area units levels) and the regular budget required for financial and operational execution (the Chilean Budgetary Affairs Bureau (DIPRES) financial report dated June 2014 has estimated USD 60 million per year for the new service).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. National level PA operational framework, which promotes cost efficiencies & optimizes conservation benefits from available funding

baseline.comment: 14 institutions related to PAs with different types of operational standards, financing and cost effectiveness and accountability

target.comment: All institutions related to PAs incorporated in SNAP, operating under common standards and under the management of the SNAP Executive Coordination Unit

actual.comment: Since it was formed, the National Protected Areas Committee (CNAP) has had six sessions (April 30, 2014, July 31, 2014, November 4, 2014, December 11, 2014, May 5, 2015 and July 7, 2015). The Committee adopted the main lines of action developed by the project (institutionality and standards, management of protected areas, financial sustainability, capacity building, dissemination and citizen awareness and international cooperation). It has prepared the first draft of the 2014-2018 Action Plan (December 2014), which is being extended to 2030, in a Logframe Matrix for the costing of activities and their inclusion in the updated National Biodiversity Strategy. The Committee is using the SNAP strategic objectives and targets proposals (Zorondo-Rodríguez, 2013) and the SNAP financial strategy (Ladrón de Guevara, 2014) as relevant inputs in this process. The project facilitator is in charge of preparing the logframe matrix and, in collaboration with BIOFIN, will calculate the costing of actions until 2030 for different scenarios that arise.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Increase in % of SNAP PAs operating under SNAP-wide certified management standard

baseline.comment: 0% (no standards or systems of certification exist for PAs in Chile)

target.comment: At least 50%, and strategy to increase to 100% in the five years following project end

actual.comment: The "Management Standards and Methodological Strengthening for Management Planning, Financial Management and Tracking and Evaluation of Protected Areas" study is being launched between January and October 2015 (led by the Center of Applied Ecology and Sustainability of the Catholic University of Chile, in collaboration with The Nature Conservancy (TNC)). The aim of this initiative is to organize, facilitate and strengthen the method used for protected areas planning, based on the Chilean National Forest Corporation's (CONAF) past experience and the conceptual framework of the Open Standards for the Practice of Conservation. It is also part of a capacity building and development process that is being carried out by the Network of Planning Specialists, which was created in November 2014 by CONAF. The focus of this proposal is the categories of SNASPE protected areas (national parks, national reserves, natural monuments) and recommendations for marine parks and marine reserves. An analysis, amendment and systematization of the Open Standards for the Practice of Conservation in the management planning of private (natural sanctuaries, etc.) and multiple use coastal and marine areas, is being carried out under a partnership agreement with the Wildlife Conservation Society Chile (WCS) and the Ministry of the Environment. It also involves practical exercises and training for private conservation initiative managers through the setting up of a learning community. As supervisor of SNASPE and private protected areas, the Ministry of the Environment will organize this process and consolidate the standards for the network of public, private, terrestrial and marine protected areas in Chile, which will enable the early implementation of regulations for the future Biodiversity and Protected Areas Service (SBAP).

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Revenue generation mechanisms are assessed and tested for increasing funding levels of SNAP PAs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Strengthened tools and systems for revenue generation and mobilization as measured by an increased score in the following 7 elements of Component 3 of UNDP Financial scorecard:
1.1 Increase in number and variety of revenue sources used across the PA system
1.2 Setting and establishment of user fees across the PA system
1.3 Effective fee collection systems
1.4 Marketing and communication strategies for revenue generation mechanisms
1.5 Operational PES schemes for PAs
1.6 Operational concessions within PAs
1.7 PA training programmes on revenue generation mechanisms

actual.comment: The results of application of the UNDP Financial Scorecard (FS) for 2015 will be available in September 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Increased GoC budget allocations for all SNAP-associated institutions (PA Management Institutions)

baseline.comment: US$ 5.7 million

actual.comment:
The results of application of the UNDP Financial Scorecard (FS) for 2015 will be available in September 2015.
Note: It is important to note that, at present, only SNASPE (managed by CONAF) has a program for protected areas with DIPRES, which makes it possible to track the budgetary development (of direct fiscal contributions and operating revenue) from 2009 onwards. It can therefore be concluded that the SNASPE executed budget in 2014 was USD $23.7 million (USD $12.9 million for direct fiscal contributions and USD $10.8 for operating revenue). Through specific consultancies, the project is contributing to the organization of the proposals for the management of own revenue and direct fiscal contributions for the CONAF SNASPE 2016 budget.
In the case of the other sub-systems (natural sanctuaries, marine reserves and parks, and multiple use marine-coastal protected areas) without a DIPRES protected areas program, the information is primarily based on the results of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard (planned for August 2015).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Increased effective allocation of resources from PA Support Institutions to specific activities identified in SNAP PAs management plans

baseline.comment: 0% of US$4.6 million

actual.comment: The 2015-2030 SNAP Financial Strategy is still in a process of study by government institutions involved, particularly the Ministry of the Environment. The project is implementing the short-term operating plan through specific actions (for example: technical guides to integrate SNAP and support areas into different subsides instruments of the National Agricultural Development Institute (INDAP) and into Regional Land Use Plans (PROT) of the Under-Secretary for Regional Development (SUBDERE); proposals for protocols and measures for changes in biodiversity in coastal and terrestrial areas in central Chile for offsetting schemes; a model for planning investments in SNASPE protected areas and marine reserves, and technical guides to focus incentives on productive estates by incorporating good practices for the biodiversity conservation). The e-Parks Program has not been launched yet, but is expected to facilitate Ministry of the Environment initiatives aimed at creating a conceptual framework and tools to develop economic instruments for biodiversity conservation within and outside the protected areas.

Of the three areas, only the Río Clarillo National Reserve receives visitor fees. The updated data on the number of visitors and revenue received will be available in August 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 1.3 Fondo Nacional de Desarrollo Regional funds allocated for work in and around PAs

baseline.comment: To be defined by end of 1st.year. The type of projects that are to be financed need first to be defined and quantified.

actual.comment:
The estimated funds from the National Fund for Regional Development (FNDR) approved and/or executed for protected areas for 2014-2015 will be available in September 2015.
Note: Within the framework of the demonstrative actions, three investment plans (Río Clarillo National Reserve, Quebrada de Cardones Natural Monument and Rinconada Marine Reserve) and three investment initiatives for regional financing will be ready in October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 2. % Regional Development Strategies refer to PAs as a specific element of strategy

actual.comment: In October 2015, a methodological guide for integrating SNAP and support areas (conservation landscapes, buffer areas and biological corridors) into Regional Land Use Plans (PROT) will be available. This initiative is led by the Ministry of the Environment and SUBDERE.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 3. Effective coordination mechanisms between PA institutions and productive sectors to foster cooperation and resolve conflicts with regard to productive sector activities within and around protected areas

baseline.comment: Conflicts are not systematically reported and do not have clear mechanisms for resolution

target.comment: Permanent Working Groups established between SNAP and 4 priority productive sector associations (tourism, mining, forestry, fisheries) by the end of project; and reduction in reported conflicts.

actual.comment: As part of the demonstrative action in the Alhué Conservation Landscape, a technical guide is being prepared to integrate good practices for biodiversity conservation in areas of great environmental value (protected areas buffer zones, conservation landscapes and biological corridors) into National Agricultural Development Institute (INDAP) productive development programs. Strategic Development Plans in SNASPE pilot protected areas are being prepared together with stakeholders in the territory (particularly tour operators). In the case of the Investment Plan in the Rinconada Marine Reserve, the Regional Ministerial Secretariat of Economic Affairs, Housing and Town Planning has been given a greater role in integrating the management of the reserve into the sectoral development agenda for the coastline (mainly small-scale fishing and tourism).

SNASPE: preliminary data obtained from the National Registry of Protected Areas (RNAP): 79% (81% of the national parks, 80% of the national reserves, and 75% of the natural monuments).
Marine Protected Areas: preliminary date obtained from the National Registry of Protected Areas (RNAP): 19% (11% of multiple use marine-coastal protected areas (MUMPA), 40% of marine reserves and 0% of marine parks).
The results of METT will confirm the validity of these data (September 2015).

actual.comment: Data on National Heritage Sites will be obtained from the METT results (September 2015). Note: Because today the environment authority does not consider National Heritage Sites as protected areas that will form part of SNAP, the National Registry of Protected Areas does not provide information on status its management plans. However, given that they are state property, the Ministry of the Environment will determine which of them should be assigned to a protected area category within the SNAP in order to improve its ecosystem representation and functionality.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
[Outcome 4, continued]
3. % staffing in SNAP with sufficient competence and skills required for their role in the system:

baseline.comment: The project will define the standards and required competences and skills for the new roles in SNAP. So, the baseline will have to be defined by the first year of project. (data below)

actual.comment:
The park rangers instructors and executors training program will be launched between July and October 2015 to begin process certification their job skills on 2016-2017. The program has places for up to 30 park ranger instructors and 170 park ranger executors and is part of a job skills certification process for park rangers prepared by CONAF and ChileValora. So far, the job skills standards proposal and course content has been prepared. A total of six courses (one for instructors and five for executors) has been planned to take place between August and October 2015.
Progress has also been made in preparing a Biodiversity and Protected Areas Service and National System of Protected Areas institutional development proposal, which covers: a) the aim of the policy and strategy unit (Ministry of the Environment) and the executive and operational unit (SBAP) of the future SNAP (at the central, regional and protected area units levels) using the SBAP and SNAP draft bill as a reference; b) the technical, operating, labor and economic requirements to provide staff for the future SNAP and SBAP at all the management levels and depending on the roles defined; c) the design of an institutional development program for setting up, launching and operating SNAP and SBAP.
The professional profile required for the adaptive management and strategic and financial planning of protected areas will be defined in October 2015, as well as a proposal for a training course to be implemented as of 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
3.1 Managerial/Higher Technical:
(a) Financial management
(b) Natural resources monitoring & conservation

baseline.comment:
(a) TBD by year 1 of project
(b) TBD by year 1 of project

actual.comment: The professional profile required for the strategic and financial planning of protected areas will be defined in October 2015, as well as a proposal for a training course to be implemented as of 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3.2 Technical/Supervisory
(a) Financial management
(b) Tourism & recreation

baseline.comment:
(a) TBD by year 1 of project
(b) TBD by year 1 of project

actual.comment:
A high-level course on adaptive management for the conservation of biodiversity and protected areas will be launched in August 2015 with the participation of 10 professionals from the Ministry of the Environment at the central and regional levels. The content of the course is based on: a) conceptual models and theories of change to identify hypotheses that can be continuously compared in an adaptive management process; b) evaluations and summaries of scientific information, specification of success criteria, and changes to models and actions, including tracking; c) including stakeholders in the adaptive management process; d) case studies in Chile and the United States. The course is sponsored by the Doctoral Program in forestry, farming and livestock development and veterinary sciences of the University of Chile, the teaching coordinator of which is Dr. Erica Fleishman (University of California, Davis).
The professional profile required for the strategic and financial planning of protected areas will be defined in October 2015, as well as a proposal for a training course to be implemented as of 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
3.3 Park Rangers (skilled workers)
(a) Tourism & recreation
(b) Natural resources monitoring & conservation

baseline.comment:
(a) TBD by year 1 of project
(b) TBD by year 1 of project

actual.comment:
The park rangers instructors and executors training program will be launched between July and October 2015 to begin process certification their job skills on 2016-2017. The program has places for up to 30 park ranger instructors and 170 park ranger executors and is part of a job skills certification process for park rangers prepared by CONAF and ChileValora. So far, the job skills standards proposal and course content has been prepared. A total of six courses (one for instructors and five for executors) has been planned to take place between August and October 2015.
The course content covers the following areas: a) evaluation of job skills (provided by ChileValora and CONAF); b) basic skills and awareness for the role of park rangers; c) knowledge of SNASPE and planning/management of protected areas (including budgetary management); d) safety awareness and skills for staff and visitors of protected areas; and e) socio-emotional development for park rangers to carry out their role accordingly (interpersonal and intrapersonal).

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 4. Degree of implementation of an Integrated Knowledge Management System (KMS) with integrated financial, operational and ecological data

baseline.comment: There is no SNAP Knowledge Management System

target.comment: By year 2, KMS established; By year 5, KMS provides needed data for SNAP system level planning and PA management plans and business plans

actual.comment:
The National Registry of Protected Areas (RNAP) is operating and has up-to-date information on a total of 162 protected areas in Chile (in the following categories: natural sanctuaries, natural monuments, national parks, national reserves, marines reserves, marine parks, multiple use marine-coastal protected areas).
By October 2015, the National Registry of Protected Areas 2.0 platform will be up and running. This will enable interoperability with the Ministry of the Environment information systems and facilitate the management of information by the National Protected Areas Committee

result.title: Objective
result.description: National policy frameworks and institutional capacities are in place to control the introduction and spread of invasive alien species (IAS) through Trade, Travel and Transport: piloting surveillance and control measures in a high biodiversity environment threatened by IAS -- the Juan Fernandez archipelago

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Strengthened Integrated Invasive species management at the national level as measured through the increase in total score of the IAS TT:
Issue
1) Is there a National Coordination Mechanism to assist with the design and implementation of a national IAS strategy?
2) Is there a National IAS strategy and is it being implemented?
3) Has the national IAS strategy lead to the development and adoption of comprehensive framework of policies, legislation, and regulations across sectors.
4) Have priority pathways for invasions been identified and actively managed and monitored?
5) Are detection, delimiting and monitoring surveys conducted on a regular basis?
6) Are best management practices being applied in project target areas?
TOTAL SCORE
TOTAL POSSIBLE

baseline.comment:
% baseline total score for IAS that impact BD: 10.3%
Baseline Scores
IAS that impact Econ. Sectors IAS that impact Biodiversity
3 1

target.comment:
% target score for IAS that impact BD: 65.5%
Target Scores
IAS that impact Econ. Sectors IAS that impact Biodiversity

actual.comment:
According to Midterm TT.
IAS’s which impact economic sectors:
4-3-5-2-4-1=19/29
IAS’s which impact biodiversity:
2-1-0-1-0-4= 8/29.
Beginning in this stage, it is the Environment Ministry’s Species Department who will be in charge of deciding on all matters regarding IAS strategies. In the resolution which formalizes this, the Operational Committee for Control of Invasive Alien Species (COCEI) is considered an advisory entity, that will support the Species Department. The Project is working jointly and developing that department to guarantee IAS action sustainability over time. Awaiting approval of the proposed legislation for establishing the Service for Biodiversity and Protected Areas (SBPA). A first step was taken in establishing this Service when on 4 March, in a constitutional proceedure, the congress approved the project’s main proposals and requested indications. The Project has contributed to the SBPA legislation indications regarding IAS management and it is following up on these.
The IAS Strategy was approved by the COCEI, but it has not yet been approved by the Executive. The Council of Ministers for Sustainability should endorse these documents to increase their impact.
The Project, jointly with the Species Department and COCEI, are working on preparing the National Action Plan for Invasive Alien Species Management (Pda_EEI) by means of general workshops (August, 2015) where the activities proposed by the COCEI will be discussed, on the basis of the strategic guidelines indicated in the National Strategy. It should be pointed out that this Plan is part of the process of up-dating the National Biodiversity Strategy (ENB), and its Biological Diversity Strategic Plans 2011-2020, and has support from the BIOFIN and GEF-IAS Projects.
On April 14, 2015, in a meeting with the SAG, a commitment was formalized in which minutes were drawn up, with participation of the following: SAG’s National Director (Angel Sartori) and their Agriculture-Forestry Division Chief (Rodrigo Astete), Natural Resources Division Chief (Roberto Rojas), and Department heads. The intention is to develop official control of some IAS’s (to be defined in a joint study), between the Continent and the JFA, a much better option than that proposed originally in the PRODOC, of voluntary control, establishing in this manner a regulatory mechanism which will be maintained over time, including establishing infrastructure and institutionalization of the measure.
Within the framework of the Project, the first stage of voluntary IAS inspections was carried out between JFA islands (from Robinson Crusoe to Alejandro Selkirk), with support from CONAF, SAG, the JFA Municipality, the Port Authority, and the Police Force. CONAF has commited itself to implementing this as a mandatory control in the islands of the Archipelago by means of an official resolution, and this is a demonstration of Project support for establishing norms which will be stable over time.
The first stage of the Clean Production Agreement (CPA) has been launched, with the JFA tourism union, involving the tourism, transport and trade sectors. The plan is to promote awareness, knowledge, behavior and actions that contribute to improving practices regarding the environment and prevent the introduction of IAS’s into the islands of this Archipelago. A CPA is a voluntary agreement between a business association that represents a productive sector and the public entities competent in issues such as the environment, health, hygiene and job security, water and energy efficiency, and developing production, whose objective is to apply Clean Production through specific targets and actions in a timeframe specified for achieving what has been agreed upon. The objective of the CPA’s is to improve productive and environmental conditions by seeking compliance with those environmental norms which tend to increase companies’ productivity and competitiveness. (www. cpl.cl/Acuerdos(APL)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of protocols under implementation for species and sites prioritized in an approved Integrated National Program for the Control of Invasive Species (PEEI)

baseline.comment:
PEEI does not exist
Existing protocols only cover IAS that threaten economically important species
No blacklist of IAS that threated biodiversity
No priority sites for IAS management

target.comment:
PEEI approved by end of year 2
Protocols in PEEI cover IAS that threaten biodiversity
Blacklist for IAS that threaten biodiversity
Priority sites defined, including islands and specific protected areas

actual.comment:
The PEEI (National Program for Prevention, Control or Eradication of IAS’s) is being drawn up jointly with the EM’s Species Department. There is already a Strategy approved by the COCEI, and together with this entity, the National Action Plan is being developed on the basis of the Strategy’s guidelines. As part of the PEEI, Regional Action Plans are being drawn up in Los Ríos, Los Lagos, Aysén and Magallanes. The University of Chile’s Center for Public Policies has been tendered the task of drawing up the four regional action plans, and as part of the agreement with Island Conservation, is drawing up the Action Plan for the Juan Fernández Island.
The legislation for establishing the SBPA which was proposed including indications regarding control and management of IAS’s which affect biodiversity, has entered into the process of congressional indications revision. The Project is monitoring this process. In addition, the first national study is being carried out for Assessing the Economic Impact of a Group of Invasive Alien Species on productive sectors and on Biodiversity in Chile. This outcome will serve as a precedent for increasing national awareness and for seeking financial mechanisms for IAS control in Chile.
The University of Concepción has been awarded the contract for drawing up the first Catalogue of naturalized species in Chile, including plants, vertebrates, invertebrates, fungi and others.
As part of the National IAS Program, work is being carried out on prioritization of areas. The Project has been working in particular on the Juan Fernández action plan, as well as supporting the 4 regions where regional action plans will be carried out, with specific actions, such as for example the efforts for eradicating mink in Chiloé and Tierra del fuego. In addition, within the agreement with Island Conservation, the possibility of replicating IAS control and management experiences on Mocha Island is being examined.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase in funding for IAS, including annual government budget allocations for IAS management in islands and protected areas, and other sources such as the National Fund for Regional Development (FNDR)

baseline.comment:
SNASPE: $2,006,479
SAG: $23,025,023
MMA: $187,822
Others: FNDR has one IAS management plan for Beavers

target.comment:
20% increase:
SNASPE: $2,407,775
SAG: $27,630,028
MMA: $225,386
Others: Target to be determined when funding gap for improved IAS management is established

actual.comment:
The finalized version of the PEEI is a basic requirement for defining future IAS financing commitments. Nonetheless, substantial financing will be generated through drawing up and implementing the Regional IAS Action Plans, which will be financed through regional funds (FNDR), as well as through Clean Production Agreements to be implemented with the trade, transport and tourism sectors that serve the JFA. This is in addition to what was reported in the 2014 PIR.
The Municipality hired a professional to take charge of Environment issues and established a Township Environment Committee (CAC), which has been very positive for Project coordination and support.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: A system of surveillance of goods and visitors entering Chilean insular ecosystems and other vulnerable sites protects biodiversity from IAS impacts

baseline.comment: Existing surveillance system only covers external borders

target.comment: Approved surveillance system in place in JFA (9,500 ha), and ready for implementation in other Chilean islands (39,700 ha) and priority protected areas (tbd)

actual.comment: The voluntary inspection system for preventing IAS entry into the JFA and their spread between these islands has been implemented successfully with CONAF, SAG, the JFA Municipality, the Port Authority, and the Police Force. However, by means of a commitment on the part of CONAF, efforts are being made to obtain a legal mandate, in the form of a resolution, that will make control mandatory.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Reduced IAS introduction rates as measured by # of IAS newly discovered outside of the inspection facilities (i.e. in the town of San Juan Bautista and nearby areas)

baseline.comment: TBD (year 1 of project)

target.comment:
At least 30%[1] reduction by end of project
[1] % reduction rate will be adjusted once baseline IAS introduction rates are confirmed

actual.comment: Since there is as yet no system of mandatory inspection and quarantine, it is not possible to determine reduction rates for IAS introduction.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: A regulatory, institutional and financial framework to combat IAS important for conservation of biodiversity is in place and operating

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Strengthened regulatory system as measured by the inclusion of IAS management in at least the following instruments:
Hunting Law / Regulations
SBAP Law
Law for Special Island Territories - Juan Fernandez Archipelago
Civil Aviation and Shipping regulations (e.g. restrictions on imports of certain products; increased inspections by airlines and shipping companies of their goods they transport, SAG Exemption Resolutions, etc.)
Tourism regulations (restrictions on products carried by civil aviation and passenger ships to the JFA, SAG Exemption Resolutions)

baseline.comment: Text concerning management of IAS that impact biodiversity does not exist in any legal instruments or regulations governing relevant sectors in Chile

target.comment: Text finalized and submitted to competent authorities for inclusion in the relevant legal instruments by end of year 1; and approved by end of project

actual.comment: Since general approval by the Senate of the proposed legislation for establishing the SBPA, in March of this year, the Project has contributed indications regarding IAS’s, drawn up by specialized lawyers who were hired for this purpose, within the relevant formal timeframe. A consultancy has been financed regarding the existance of legal bodies, analysing the national legal frameworks for IAS management in Chile. However, the Project can do np more than propose indications and then make them available to the Government and the legislative branch.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of targets in the officially approved annual workplan of the National Operating Committee for Inter-Sectoral Control of IAS (COCEI) achieved by participating institutions: MMA, SAG, CONAF, MINAGRI, SERNAPESCA, SUBPESCA, DIRECTEMAR, FACH, DINAMAR, and Natural History Museum

baseline.comment:
COCEI operating without formal status or annual workplans
0%

target.comment:
Legal instrument for COCEI, with specific annual targets, published by end of year 3
80% by end of project

actual.comment: The Project succeeded in obtaining formal establishment of the COCEI by means of the Environment Ministry’s Exempt Resolution N° 684 of 09 March 2013. The Project has sought to strengthen the COCEI in view of the roles it is assigned in the PRODOC. However, because of the COCEI’s legal definition, in practice it serves only as an advisory body. This shortcoming could translate into a lack of institutional sustainability for the IAS policies, strategies, programs in Chile. For this reason, the Midterm Evaluation (MTE) recommended reinforcing that advisory role. Until the SBPA legislation is finalized, the EM Species Department will fill the executive role and together with the Council of Ministers for Sustainability, review and approve policy documents regarding IAS’s. With the Species Department playing a major role in drawing up the PEEI, this constitutes successful effective institucionalization and appropriation of the Invasive Alien Species issues on the part of this Ministerial Department.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Traveling public, tourism operators, importers and shipping agents aware of risks posed by IAS to vulnerable biodiversity

baseline.comment: No specific information targeting tourism operators, importers and shipping agents. In general, little awareness of IAS detrimental to biodiversity

target.comment: Agreements with all airlines and tourism operators that travel to the JFA and other Chilean islands to provide information on IAS to their passengers

actual.comment:
Progress on these matters has been substantial: with the tourism, transport and trade operators who offer services in the JFA, a CPA was signed which includes, among other environmental issues, that of IAS management. This agreement was achieved between the UNDP, the GEF-IAS Project, and the Executive Direction of the Economy Ministry’s Clean Production Council.
This is in addition to what was achieved in the previous period, regarding information which the shipping companies must provide to their customers, and regarding facilities granted to State entities for controlling IAS entry into the JFA from the Continent.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Increased institutional capacity of key institutions (CONAF, SAG, MMA-SNASPE, Regional Authorities, DIRECTEMAR, Carabineros, PDI, IMJF) to manage IAS detrimental to biodiversity, as measured by:
Updated technical procedures that address IAS (SAG)
New technical staff and competencies (SNASPE)
Regional planning procedures that incorporate IAS

baseline.comment:
SAG currently only applies inspection at borders and to species identified for economic interests
IAS is not included as a competency in SNASPE requirements and only 25% of staff have IAS understanding
Regional planning procedures and risk management do not cover IAS
There is no agreed upon IAS capacity development index for PEEI implementation and currently only 15% of staff in key institutions understand IAS issues

target.comment:
By end of project:
SAG has developed specific technical procedures for species prioritized in the PEEI, and at sites including the JFA and at least two other priority sites
IAS is included as a competency in SNASPE (new SBAP) staff requirements and at least 50% of staff have detailed knowledge and skills defined.
Regional planning procedures and risk management include IAS
There is at least a 50% increase in the IAS capacity index above baseline established by end of year 1 for each of the following institutions: CONAF; SAG; MMA; Juan Fernandez Municipality

actual.comment:
A consultancy, drawn up jointly with SAG, is being tendered for improving the present risk assessment system applied by SAG, based on the Proceedure for Allowing Entry of Wild Fauna into the national territory, along with another consultancy, drawn up by SAG, already awarded, for compiling and organizing the information necessary to draw up a “Risk Assessment of Infestations for the Juan Fernández Archipelago”.
The Midterm Evaluation recommended adding indicators for the institutionalization of outcomes, where it was stipulated that (an as yet undetermined number of) professionals from the counterpart institutions be granted a Degree in IAS’s approved by a prestigious institution. This was determined because during the first stage of the Project, a study of existing inter-institutional capabilities was carried out, with an education and training actions proposal, including certification, that would contribute to strengthening the Project’s institutional sustainability and IAS policy continuity in Chile. The terms of reference for this Degree are already being drawn up and it should be tendered this year. A specific training event was the joint effort with CONAF regarding the Vespula germánica (yellow jacket): a training workshop was carried out for 30 park rangers on management and control, for practical application in parks and reserves.
Preparation of the regional plans for Los Ríos, Los Lagos, Aysén and Magallanes has been tendered. The intention is to succeed in Incorporating IAS’s into regional planning and risk management.
In order to improve knowledge and abilities regarding IAS’s within different public and private institutions, the first conference on Private Areas and IAS’s in Chile was organized by the GEF Project, with the participation of 70 people representing more than 30 private areas, and with the Environment Minister, the National SAG Director and the UNDP Environment and Energy Programme Officer present. During the Conference, a commitment was reached between the private concerns and the Project to advance with Product 1.4 regarding institutions and productive sectors in IAS management. In addition, we have available 1000 publications dealing with IAS’s on both the national and international levels, including scientific papers, chapters from books, press releases, among others. These will help to complement the national data base that is currently being set up for the whole country.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
IAS management plans for other priority Chilean Islands (Easter Island; Desventuradas Islands; Mocha Island; Sala y Gomez Island)
IAS strategy for Chileâ€™s National System of Protected Areas (SNASPE)

baseline.comment:
No IAS management plans exist
No IAS strategy exists for SNASPE

target.comment:
At least 2 plans drafted by end of project
Strategy drafted by end of project

actual.comment:
Work is going forward on draft management plans for Juan Fernández and Mocha Island as part of the agreement with Island Conservation. In addition to this, the text of the Regional Plans will include supplementary information regarding Chiloé and Tierra del Fuego, which although included in their respective Regional Plans, will be provided with more precise Action Plan imputs for their specific characteristics as island territories. In this second stage, efforts will be carried out on the drafts of two additional Action Plans, for Desventuradas and Mocha Islands.
Together with CONAF, guidelines have been drawn up on best practices in IAS management and control in both continental and island protected areas, as well as the role that hiking trails play in these issues. The consultancies that have been carried out have made available very high quality material for including IAS best practices in SNASPE area management plans, an issue which must be taken up with CONAF during this phase.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Integrated IAS Control System in place as a pilot project in the Juan Fernandez Archipelago and developing tools and strategies to be replicated at the national level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of goods and visitors entering the JFA by sea and air that are subjected to IAS inspection procedures

actual.comment: The inspection proceedures that are being implemented are voluntary and lack legal underpinnings. Formalizing the inspection system is a task for public institutions (SAG, CONAF). A formal commitment has been made by both of these institutions to proceed with legal formalization of the above.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
A financed IAS Management Plan for the Juan Fernandez Archipelago under implementation, as measured by:
Approved plan
Increased financing at JFA level
Best management practices being applied in Juan Fernandez as measured by item 6 of the GEF TT for IAS applied in JFA

baseline.comment:
No plans for IAS management in the JFA exist
Financing
CONAF: $284,560
SAG: $56,832
Municipality: $15,673
Baseline Scores
IAS that impact econ. sectors | IAS that impact biodiversity
1 | 0

target.comment:
Initial plan approved by end of year 1; Final plan approved by end of project
40% increase:
CONAF: $398,384
SAG: $79,565
Municipality: $21,942
Target Scores
IAS that impact econ. sectors | IAS that impact biodiversity
5 | 5

actual.comment:
An initial JFA action plan is now available, and this year those responsible must specify and validate these actions. This action plan will be included in the PEEI which to date consists of a Strategy and a National Action Plan. Once these are approved, they will be presented to the Regional Government of the 5th Region, to incorporate them into public policy and give them access to financing through the Regional Development Fund.
With the JF Municipality hiring a professional in charge of these issues, they have surpassed the committed value (calculations will be given in detail at the end of this year).
CONAF has made contributions in kind, through management of the bio-security barrier between islands, the work of their lawyer on legislation for the exempt resolution, and hiring seasonal workers. The exact figures will be available by the end of 2015. SAG has been carrying out yellow jacket control operations for two years, and they have developed activities on the Island and the Continent to set up the voluntary barrier and in training. The commitment to set up a mandatory barrier will mean an increase in SAG’s direct contributions for implementation and for hiring personnel, a situation which will be reflected in the 2016 PIR. International financing has been obtained (about USD 400,000), through a project presented by CABI with support from the GEF-IAS Project, for protecting the JFA’s genetic heritage which is at the present time threatened by IAS’s. In addition, a cooperation agreement was signed with the Conservatory in Brest, France, for the purpose of jointly developing an endemic plant conservatory in the JFA. The exact values of the commitment have not yet been determined because a new meeting is to be held in France for work on the action plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Early Warning System for IAS in the Juan Fernandez Archipelago with the participation of all key partners (SAG, CONAF, IMJF and the inhabitants of San Juan Bautista)

baseline.comment: No system or procedures exist for responding to new IAS entries into the JFA

target.comment: Early Warning System is fully functional by mid-term of project; reduction in average time to implement response activities following alerts by end of project

actual.comment:
1) In this second Project phase, work has begun on drawing up Early Warning systems and proceedures. The Project is presently working on a revision of methodologies in this area, and a workshop will be held in November jointly financed by the Tantauco Park, with representatives of the EM, CONAF, SAG, NGO’s and private protected areas, for the purpose of developing a SAT protocol for island eco-systems. In the specific case of the JFA, a protocol is being drawn up together with CONAF.
By the time of the next period, the protocol should have been validated by the institutions and be operating on a trial basis on the island of Juan Fernández.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Control activities reduce populations of key aggressive IAS within the JFA and provide best practices and know-how for up-scaling and replication at other sites over the long-term
Control of invasive fauna (rodents) and flora reduces pressures on, and expands available habitat for, the Masafuera Rayadito, leading to population increases of this critically endangered endemic species. To be measured by the number of successful nesting boxes
Control of invasive blackberry and maqui that displace native species and disrupt ecological functioning in native forests on Alejandro Selkirk
Increased populations of endemic Juan Fernandez Hummingbird through control of invasive blackberry and maqui on Robinson Crusoe island as measured by the increase in the # of successful nests
Control of yellow jacket (Vespula germanica) on Robinson Crusoe island: Number of queens captured in bait traps

baseline.comment:
Number of successful Rayadito nesting boxes will be measured at start of control work
(Masafuera Rayadito pop. in the southern zone of Alejandro Selkirk is estimated : 250 individuals )
150 ha
Number of successful nest will be measured at start of blackberry conrtol work (baseline number of hummingbirds is estimated at 400)
# of queens captured at start of 1st season

target.comment:
An increase in 20% of successful Rayadito nesting boxes by end of project
Reduced to 100 ha by end of project
Increase of 20% in successful nest of endemic hummingbird in the blackberry control area
80% reduction by end of project

actual.comment:
Regarding nesting of the rayadito, the actions taken did not prosper because the design of the nests was not adequate. During the second stage, adaptations of the design will be tested. In addition, efforts are being made to improve the baseline in order to estimate their population and tendencies. The MTE recommended revising the biological indicators, and the new one proposed for the Rayadito measures the use % of the different nest unit designs.
Regarding blackberry control, this species has been reduced over a 4 ha surface area, specifically in forest clearings. In addition, a maintenance process has been carried out (elimination of propagators) in a 12-ha surface area on Robinson Crusoe. The MTE suggests that the Project focus on highly effective and low cost control methods in order to provide replicable models, rather than trying to cover a larger number of hectares. The additional activities generated by changes to the indicator are being included in the new agreement with OIKONOS.
As a lesson learned, the Project has confirmed that it is impossible to control blackberry by the traditional methods utilized to date. For this reason, it has promoted the need for investigating biological control methods that would make effective control possible, and so a multi-sectorial work group has been formed under the direction of CONAF’s Biological Diversity Department, and including participation of the following: CONAF, INIA, CABI (Center for Agricultural Bioscience International), Austral University, the EM, FIA and the GEF-IAS Project. In the new agreement with OIKONOS, we are seeing improvement in the efforts for improving the hummingbird’s habitat in forest clearings, through comparing the IAS-invaded surface areas in clearings where different control methodologies have been applied. This is the result of modifications to the biological indicators recommended in the MTE.
Regarding the Vespula germánica (yellow jacket), progress has been made in drawing up a control strategy for the island. However, the MTE and the specialists suggest that it is necessary to seek a methodology to replace evaluation by capture of queens, since this is not efficient. The indicator must be revised.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Reduction in the number of IAS flora species (small, incipient populations) within the JFA and best practices for cost-effective IAS management for replication at other sites in Chile

baseline.comment:
46 incipient invasive flora species on Robinson Crusoe (area of San Juan Bautista and neighbouring lands within National Park)
14 invasive flora species on Alejandro Selkirk (area of Rada la Colonia)

target.comment:
Eradication of 50% (23) of incipient invasive flora species by end of project
Eradication of 50% (7) invasive flora species by end of project

actual.comment: The incipient species eradication work, both on Alejandro Selkirk and on Robinson Crusoe, has been highly effective, and we believe that the target will be met. To the present, we have succeeded in identifying, locating and nearly eradicating 23 IAS’s in San Juan Bautista and 7 in Alejandro Selkirk. In addition, the work carried out by the NGO’s OIKONOS and IC, has been incorporated into the community awareness efforts, through the Environmental Education and Awareness project, with a Focus on Gender. An anthropological study was carried out regarding the inhabitants’ concept of their environment, nature and the institutions present on the Island, which can serve as a diagnosis to support the awareness efforts in the JFA.
